awd_titl_txt: Spokes: MEDIUM: MIDWEST: Smart Big Data Pipeline for Aging Rural Bridge Transportation Infrastructure (SMARTI)
awd_abstract_narration:
America's bridges received a C+ from the American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE) in 2017. Additionally, the US ranks only 11th world-wide in terms of infrastructure competitiveness. America's infrastructure, particularly its 50-100+ year-old bridges, is in poor health, representing a hidden crisis. Rural areas, due to their lower population density and distance from urban centers, are acutely affected by this crisis, particularly in terms of public safety and economic growth. Limited budgets for planning and maintenance only serve to exacerbate the crisis. To better inform future research, the research team held collaborative conferences and workshops, and conducted stakeholder surveys to identify issues impacting rural bridge health. Outcomes from these activities underscored the value of big data technologies to address the crisis and informed the proposed work. The mission of this multi-institution and multi-sector project is to produce a big data pipeline for rural bridge health management that improves transportation network performance and enhances safety.

The research team will combine existing and new datasets to address challenges of relevance to bridge owners using scalable and replicable big data pipeline components. Activities will inform bridge owner decision-making by integrating existing datasets and data collected using next-generation health monitoring technologies (e.g., contact and non-contact sensors, unmanned aerial vehicles) with innovative data management techniques. Socio-technical impacts associated with potential decisions will also be assessed. Aging, rural bridge testbeds will be selected in consultation with public and private owners to produce data products that facilitate decision-making and ultimately, provide economical and reliable solutions that improve bridge health. Results from the research will be shared with engineers, owners, and builders at workshops hosted by the research team. Project findings will be disseminated through publications, conferences, meetings, and forums. The research team will engage with the Big Data Hubs and Spokes network to make data, methods, and results available across regions. By extension, project findings will also benefit activities used to monitor and manage other important infrastructure assets, including highways, buildings, power grids, offshore oil platforms, water networks, and other civil infrastructures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The major outcomes of this project include improvements of on-device machine learning for bridge inspection, interpretable machine learning in the bridge domain, path planning, and Bayesian methods that account for bridge health.

On-Device Machine Learning

In order to get real time information about bridge health, we have developed techniques for using modern artificial intelligence (AI) at bridge sites and on drones.

In this part of the specific, we specifically focus on the crucial task of crack detection. The primary goal of the crack detection process is to segment cracks based on image-level labels with minimum human intervention, reducing the costs and time associated with manual labeling while avoiding bias from erroneous human annotations. We use a cloud-edge adaptive intelligence framework to perform crack detection tasks in real-time physical sites. The framework incorporates a novel edge-AI framework, the crowd intelligence approach, and the CrANET framework to perform weakly supervised crack segmentation. Google Coral dev-board are employed to carry out edge-AI experiments. We also created and front end to demonstrate the practical implementation of the framework, user interaction, and the effectiveness of the CEAIC framework. This study has the potential to provide a cost-effective and reliable solution for real-time monitoring and assessment of bridge cracks, thereby improving the safety and longevity of bridges. The outcomes of this research endeavor will furnish us with invaluable insights regarding the feasibility and potential advantages of incorporating edge-AI into the SHM domain.

Another approach we take is the use reinforcement learning, which is a machine learning training method based on rewarding desired behaviors. Additionally, Deep Reinforcement learning is applied to the national bridge inventory dataset to explore bridge maintenance parameters. The repairs are scheduled based on past data of condition ratings and transition probabilities. The problem is formulated as a Markov Decision Process and is solved with Dueling Deep Q Network (D3QN) algorithm.

Interpretable Machine Learning

We have developed a visualization tool for model explanation of decision trees, which was published at ISCRAM conference. We also created  more  expressive tool for explaining deep learning models, which are traditionally more difficult to understand. Using interpretable machine learning statistics and comparisons, we have developed algorithms and methodologies to compare various models for bridge condition assessment and maintenance prediction. To improve the usability of these technologies, we have also created an accessible machine learning framework based on state-of-the-art ML tools that enhances human involvement and evaluation of machine learning lifecycle.

Combined, these algorithms and technologies will improve bridge stake holder’s abilities to predict the maintenance needs of their bridges with more confidence.

Path Planning

Our innovations in bridge repair and health prediction allow us to use these predictions on concrete ways, such as path planning that takes bridge health into account. During this grant, we have developed algorithms and methodologies including the generation of a novel bridge health informed GIS dataset, the development of a route visualization tool that uses the generated dataset, and the production of multiple routes completely offline. We are also developing adversarial simulation in presence of attacker on bridges, which can be used to inform convoys about the safest routes.

These technologies are designed for end-users to make wise path planning predictions using the state-of-the-art algorithms we have developed.

Bayesian Estimation

In association with this project, in the domain of bridge structural health monitoring, our impactful contributions involved pioneering the development of recursive Bayesian estimation and machine learning algorithms tailored for model updating, validation, and damage identification. The innovative methods that we built, were distinguished by their robustness, effectively navigating challenges associated with modeling uncertainties, sensor noise, and unknown external inputs. Notably, these methods have undergone rigorous validation through extensive full-scale tests and experiments conducted on operational structures. This robust testing has not only affirmed the reliability of the developed algorithms but has also demonstrated their efficacy in real-world scenarios. This comprehensive approach underscores a commitment to advancing structural health monitoring systems, ensuring their precision and resilience in identifying and addressing potential damages while operating under operational and varying environmental conditions.

 


Last Modified: 12/15/2023
Modified by: Brian C Ricks

por.por_txt_cntn:
The major outcomes of this project include improvements of on-device machine learning for bridge inspection, interpretable machine learning in the bridge domain, path planning, and Bayesian methods that account for bridge health.
On-Device Machine Learning


In order to get real time information about bridge health, we have developed techniques for using modern artificial intelligence (AI) at bridge sites and on drones.


In this part of the specific, we specifically focus on the crucial task of crack detection. The primary goal of the crack detection process is to segment cracks based on image-level labels with minimum human intervention, reducing the costs and time associated with manual labeling while avoiding bias from erroneous human annotations. We use a cloud-edge adaptive intelligence framework to perform crack detection tasks in real-time physical sites. The outcomes of this research endeavor will furnish us with invaluable insights regarding the feasibility and potential advantages of incorporating edge-AI into the SHM domain.


Another approach we take is the use reinforcement learning, which is a machine learning training method based on rewarding desired behaviors. Additionally, Deep Reinforcement learning is applied to the national bridge inventory dataset to explore bridge maintenance parameters. The repairs are scheduled based on past data of condition ratings and transition probabilities. The problem is formulated as a Markov Decision Process and is solved with Dueling Deep Q Network (D3QN) algorithm.

To improve the usability of these technologies, we have also created an accessible machine learning framework based on state-of-the-art ML tools that enhances human involvement and evaluation of machine learning lifecycle.

During this grant, we have developed algorithms and methodologies including the generation of a novel bridge health informed GIS dataset, the development of a route visualization tool that uses the generated dataset, and the production of multiple routes completely offline. The innovative methods that we built, were distinguished by their robustness, effectively navigating challenges associated with modeling uncertainties, sensor noise, and unknown external inputs. Notably, these methods have undergone rigorous validation through extensive full-scale tests and experiments conducted on operational structures. This robust testing has not only affirmed the reliability of the developed algorithms but has also demonstrated their efficacy in real-world scenarios. This comprehensive approach underscores a commitment to advancing structural health monitoring systems, ensuring their precision and resilience in identifying and addressing potential damages while operating under operational and varying environmental conditions.
